questions.text: Which is correct about Diphtheria membrane?

options.label: A
options.text: Grey membrane that bleeds on removal

options.label: B
options.text: Grey membrane that does not bleed on removal

options.label: C
options.text: Grey pseudo-membrane that bleeds on removal

options.label: D
options.text: Grey pseudo-membrane that does not bleed on removal

questions.correct_answer: C. Grey pseudo-membrane that bleeds on removal
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Grey pseudo-membrane that bleeds on removal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A diphtheria pseudomembrane is grey in color and bleeds if attempts are made to remove it.
  • ➤ Note :
  • ➤ Note :
  • ➤ Diphtheria affects three systems: the heart (causing carditis), the nerves (causing neuritis), and the adrenal glands (causing adrenal hemorrhage). Diphtheria is caused by a toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, not by the bacteria itself. The pseudomembrane associated with diphtheria is caused by the bacteria, not the toxin. The treatment of choice for diphtheria is antitoxin , as the disease is toxin mediated. Antibiotics, such as erythromycin, are used to kill the bacteria and prevent further toxin production. However, antibiotics cannot neutralize the toxin already present in the bloodstream.
  • ➤ Diphtheria affects three systems: the heart (causing carditis), the nerves (causing neuritis), and the adrenal glands (causing adrenal hemorrhage).
  • ➤ Diphtheria is caused by a toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, not by the bacteria itself.
  • ➤ The pseudomembrane associated with diphtheria is caused by the bacteria, not the toxin. The treatment of choice for diphtheria is antitoxin , as the disease is toxin mediated.
  • ➤ antitoxin
  • ➤ Antibiotics, such as erythromycin, are used to kill the bacteria and prevent further toxin production. However, antibiotics cannot neutralize the toxin already present in the bloodstream.

questions.text: Metachromatic granules can be stained by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Albert stain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metachromatic granules are bluish-violet granules that appear at the poles of certain bacteria and are stained using specific stains like Albert stain. They are also known as Babes-Ernst granules, volutin granules, or polar bodies.

questions.text: Identify the organism:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nocardia species

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nocardia species is characterized by its branching, filamentous structure and its ability to retain red staining in acid-fast tests.

questions.text: Lysogenic conversion is:

options.label: A
options.text: Integration of host bacterial nucleic acid to phage

options.label: B
options.text: Integration of phage nucleic acid to host bacteria genome

options.label: C
options.text: Bacterial mechanism to cause antigenic shift

questions.correct_answer: B. Integration of phage nucleic acid to host bacteria genome
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Integration of phage nucleic acid to host bacteria genome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lysogenic conversion involves the integration of bacteriophage genetic material into the bacterial genome, leading to potential changes in the bacterium's traits.

questions.text: Microscopic picture of stool sample of a patient is given. What is the mode of transmission of the parasite?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Feco-oral transmission

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The transmission of Trichuris trichiura occurs via the feco-oral route, where contaminated food or water leads to ingestion of eggs that hatch in the host's intestine .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: In Robertson cooked meat media, meat color will change to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Red

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Robertson Cooked Meat medium, anaerobic bacterial growth causes a reduction reaction that changes the meat color to red, indicating active metabolism.

questions.text: The following picture of an egg belongs to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Necator americanus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of non-bile stained, transparent eggs with four blastomeres is indicative of hookworm species like Necator americanus or Ancylostoma duodenale.

questions.text: Lancefield classification is done on the basis of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) C-substance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Lancefield classification system is based on the presence of specific C-carbohydrate antigens in the cell walls of beta-hemolytic Streptococci.

questions.text: Bacillus anthracis is:

options.label: B
options.text: Gram positive rods with square ends

options.label: C
options.text: Gram positive bacilli with spherical ends

questions.correct_answer: B. Gram positive rods with square ends
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gram-positive rods with square ends

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bacillus anthracis is identified as a Gram-positive, rod-shaped bacterium with square ends and a bamboo-stick arrangement .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: When should you perform the Widal test in a case of Typhoid?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2nd week

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Widal test for diagnosing typhoid fever is best performed in the 2nd week of infection when antibodies are most likely to be detectable.

questions.text: Out of 20 children that went to the party, 11 developed abdominal pain, diarrhea with nausea and vomiting around 4 hours after food intake. Most likely causative agent:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Food poisoning with rapid onset of symptoms (2-6 hours) after ingestion is often caused by Staphylococcus aureus, due to its preformed enterotoxins.

questions.text: HUS is caused by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) O157: H7 of EHEC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) serotype O157: H7 is specifically responsible for causing Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) and hemorrhagic colitis, in addition to diarrhea.
  • ➤ O157: H7
  • ➤ Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)

questions.text: Gas gangrene is caused by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Clostridium perfringens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clostridium perfringens is the primary bacterium responsible for gas gangrene, producing both acid and gas during glucose fermentation, leading to tissue necrosis and gas accumulation in affected areas.
  • ➤ Clostridium perfringens
  • ➤ acid and gas

questions.text: A female from Himachal Pradesh presented with verrucous lesion growth on the skin with the following microscopic finding. Identify the agent:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chromoblastomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis is identified by verrucous lesions and brown, septate fungal bodies (sclerotic bodies or Medlar bodies) resembling copper pennies on biopsy.
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis
  • ➤ verrucous lesions
  • ➤ brown, septate fungal bodies
  • ➤ copper pennies

questions.text: Anchovy Sauce pus/chocolate brown pus is the clinical feature of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Amoebic liver abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anchovy sauce-like pus is a hallmark feature of an amoebic liver abscess caused by Entamoeba histolytica and results from the necrosis of liver tissue due to invasive trophozoites.
  • ➤ Anchovy sauce-like pus
  • ➤ amoebic liver abscess
  • ➤ Entamoeba histolytica

questions.text: A young woman presents with progressive dyspnea for 3 months. A cavitatory lesion was detected in the right lower lobe of the lung and lobectomy was performed. Histopathological picture is given. Most likely cause of the disease and the number of layers seen in the wall:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Echinococcus with 3 layers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The three-layered structure (pericyst, ectocyst, endocyst) is a characteristic feature of hydatid cysts caused by Echinococcus granulosus .
  • ➤ three-layered structure
  • ➤ hydatid cysts
  • ➤ Echinococcus granulosus

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-motile bacteria?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Klebsiella pneumoniae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Klebsiella pneumoniae is a non-motile bacterium because it lacks flagella, making it unable to move like other motile bacteria such as E. coli , Helicobacter pylori , and Vibrio cholerae .
  • ➤ Klebsiella pneumoniae
  • ➤ non-motile bacterium
  • ➤ E. coli
  • ➤ Helicobacter pylori
  • ➤ Vibrio cholerae

questions.text: All are true about the bacteria shown below except:

options.label: B
options.text: Pike’s media is a transport media

options.label: C
options.text: Streptolysin S is an oxygen labile hemolysin

options.label: D
options.text: Streptodornase DNAse depolymerizes the viscous DNA

questions.correct_answer: C. Streptolysin S is an oxygen labile hemolysin
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Streptolysin S is an oxygen labile hemolysin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptolysin S, produced by Streptococcus pyogenes, is an oxygen-stable hemolysin, while Streptolysin O is oxygen-labile. Understanding the characteristics of bacterial toxins is crucial for identifying and differentiating Streptococcus infections.
  • ➤ Streptolysin S, produced by Streptococcus pyogenes, is an oxygen-stable hemolysin, while Streptolysin O is oxygen-labile.

questions.text: Blood culture of a patient shows growth of gram-positive cocci which are catalase-positive and coagulase-negative. The patient was on a CVP line last week. The most likely etiological agent is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus epidermidis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a history of CVP line placement, when gram-positive cocci that are catalase-positive and coagulase-negative are identified, Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most likely causative agent.
  • ➤ Staphylococcus epidermidis

questions.text: A patient presented with some unknown fungal infection. Microscopic examination revealed brown-colored spherical fungi with septate hyphae. Possible condition:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chromoblastomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis is diagnosed by the presence of brown, spherical fungi with septate hyphae , often described as resembling “copper pennies” in appearance under the microscope. This characteristic appearance is key for identifying the condition.
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis
  • ➤ brown, spherical fungi with septate hyphae

questions.text: A known HIV-infected patient develops diarrhea. Fecal examination shows Isospora belli. He was treated with TMP-SMX. Diarrhea subsided, but fever persisted. Bone marrow examination showed the following picture with an intracellular fungus. Which of the following is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: It cannot be grown in SDA

questions.correct_answer: D. Does not cause disseminated disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Does not cause disseminated disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histoplasma capsulatum is an intracellular fungus that can cause disseminated infections in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV. It can be identified microscopically by its presence inside macrophages and is not easily cultured on standard fungal media.
  • ➤ disseminated infections

questions.text: Which is correct about the larval stage of Taenia solium?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cysticercus cellulosae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The larval stage of Taenia solium is Cysticercus cellulosae , which can cause cysticercosis when humans ingest Taenia eggs, leading to the development of cysts in tissues like muscle and the central nervous system.
  • ➤ Cysticercus cellulosae

questions.text: Classical complement activated by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ag – Ab complex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classical complement pathway is activated by the presence of antigen-antibody complexes , specifically involving IgG or IgM . This activation then triggers the complement protein C1 to start the cascade.
  • ➤ classical complement pathway
  • ➤ antigen-antibody complexes
  • ➤ IgG
  • ➤ IgM
  • ➤ C1

questions.text: Lung biopsy of a neutropenic patient shows the following organism on staining. Identify the organism:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aspergillus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergillus is characterized by narrow, septate hyphae with acute (45-degree) branching , making it a common cause of opportunistic infections, especially in neutropenic patients. It is important to differentiate it from Mucor and Rhizopus , which have broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching.
  • ➤ Aspergillus
  • ➤ narrow, septate hyphae
  • ➤ acute (45-degree) branching
  • ➤ neutropenic
  • ➤ Mucor
  • ➤ Rhizopus

questions.text: Tetanus toxin acts by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Presynaptic blocking

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetanus toxin causes presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine , leading to uncontrolled muscle contraction and spastic paralysis . This is distinct from the mechanism of botulinum toxin, which inhibits acetylcholine release and leads to flaccid paralysis.
  • ➤ presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine
  • ➤ uncontrolled muscle contraction
  • ➤ spastic paralysis

questions.text: Father of medical microbiology:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Robert Koch

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Robert Koch is known as the father of medical microbiology for his contributions to identifying microbial causes of diseases and establishing foundational principles in the field.
  • ➤ Robert Koch
  • ➤ father of medical microbiology

questions.text: A patient was exposed to hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present irrespective of whether the patient recovers from the infection or not?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anti-HBc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-HBc is the marker that remains detectable in a patient who has been exposed to hepatitis B, regardless of whether they recover or develop chronic infection. It is indicative of past or present infection with hepatitis B.

questions.text: HIV target binding site:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) gp120, gp41

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HIV utilizes gp120 for attachment to the CD4 receptor and gp41 for subsequent fusion with the host cell membrane, enabling entry into the host cell.
  • ➤ gp120
  • ➤ gp41

questions.text: Culture media are sterilized by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Autoclaving

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autoclaving is the preferred method for sterilizing most culture media, using steam under pressure to ensure complete sterilization. For heat-sensitive media, alternative methods like tyndallization are used.

questions.text: Which of the following life cycle is shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diphyllobothrium latum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm) is acquired through the consumption of raw or undercooked fish containing L3 larva . It is characterized by a life cycle that involves:
  • ➤ Diphyllobothrium latum
  • ➤ raw or undercooked fish
  • ➤ L3 larva
  • ➤ Definitive host → Man
  • ➤ 1 st Intermediate host → Cyclops / diaptomus 2 nd Intermediate host → Fresh water Fish
  • ➤ 1 st Intermediate host → Cyclops / diaptomus
  • ➤ 2 nd Intermediate host → Fresh water Fish

questions.text: Which of the following stimulates adenylate cyclase with G-protein coupled action?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cholera toxin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholera toxin activates adenylate cyclase through G-protein coupled action, leading to increased cAMP levels and severe watery diarrhea, distinguishing it from other toxins that primarily inhibit protein synthesis.
  • ➤ Cholera toxin

questions.text: Which antibody is most commonly produced in the secondary immune response?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IgG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IgG is the main antibody produced during the secondary immune response , enabling a faster, stronger, and more specific immune reaction due to the presence of memory cells .
  • ➤ IgG
  • ➤ secondary immune response
  • ➤ memory cells

questions.text: Following Foley’s catheterization, a patient in the ICU developed a urinary tract infection (UTI). The catheter tip was sent for culture and grown on blood agar. The blood agar picture after 24 hours is shown. The most likely agent causing UTI is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Proteus mirabilis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The swarming pattern on blood agar is a hallmark of Proteus mirabilis, which is also associated with catheter-associated UTIs. This characteristic helps distinguish it from other potential UTI pathogens.

questions.text: Rearrange the sequence of hand washing:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1-a; 2-c; 3-d; 4-b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Proper handwashing involves sequentially cleaning the palms, backs of hands, between fingers, and thumbs , following the WHO guidelines for effective hand hygiene.
  • ➤ palms, backs of hands, between fingers, and thumbs
  • ➤ WHO guidelines

questions.text: Which among the following exists in yeast form at 37°C and hyphal form at 25°C?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Histoplasma capsulatum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histoplasma capsulatum is an example of a dimorphic fungus , existing in yeast form at 37°C and hyphal (mold) form at 25°C , making it capable of adapting to both environmental and host conditions.
  • ➤ Histoplasma capsulatum
  • ➤ dimorphic fungus
  • ➤ yeast form
  • ➤ 37°C
  • ➤ hyphal (mold) form
  • ➤ 25°C

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) a-4, b-1, c-2, d-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Proper segregation of biomedical waste into appropriate containers and bags is essential for safe disposal, minimizing the risk of contamination and ensuring compliance with waste management regulations.
  • ➤ segregation of biomedical waste

questions.text: Auto-infection is not seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) H. diminuta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Auto-infection is seen in parasites like H. nana, Strongyloides, Enterobius, and Taenia solium, but not in H. diminuta.

questions.text: The following plate shows H. influenzae colonies. Which of the following is responsible for the phenomenon shown? -
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) V factor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The satellitism phenomenon seen with H. influenzae growing near Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar is due to the release of V factor (NAD) , which is necessary for the growth of H. influenzae alongside the freely available X factor.
  • ➤ V factor (NAD)

questions.text: Identify the organism in the Gram staining slide picture.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a Gram-negative diplococcus, often appearing as kidney-shaped cocci in pairs within white blood cells on a Gram stain. It is distinguished from other Gram-positive cocci like Staphylococcus and Streptococcus and from Gram-negative rods like Haemophilus influenzae.

questions.text: Correct order of gram staining is:

options.label: A
options.text: Gent ion violet → Iodine → Carbol fuchsin

questions.correct_answer: A. Gent ion violet → Iodine → Carbol fuchsin
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gentian violet → Iodine → Carbol fuchsin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of Gram staining involves applying gentian violet as the primary stain, followed by iodine as the mordant, and then carbol fuchsin or safranin as the counterstain after decolorization

questions.text: An adolescent girl is brought with fever and chills for 3 days. Examination reveals signs of dehydration (positive skin pinch test and dry oral mucosa). Peripheral blood smear picture is given below. Identify the species of malarial parasite:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Plasmodium falciparum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plasmodium falciparum is identified by the presence of multiple ring forms in a single RBC and its characteristic "headphone" or "accolé" appearance in blood smears. This differentiates it from other malarial species like P. vivax, P. malariae, and P. ovale, which typically have single rings per RBC.

questions.text: All of the following are spore-forming bacteria except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vibrio cholerae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spore formation is a feature seen in certain bacteria like Bacillus and Clostridium. Vibrio cholerae does not produce spores, which distinguishes it from other options in this question. The mnemonic "BSC Chemistry" can help remember the key spore-forming genera.

questions.text: Which is enrichment media?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Selenite F broth

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enrichment media are typically liquid media that contain substances promoting the growth of certain microorganisms while inhibiting others. Examples include Selenite F broth , Tetrathionate broth , and alkaline peptone water .
  • ➤ liquid
  • ➤ Selenite F broth
  • ➤ Tetrathionate broth
  • ➤ alkaline peptone water

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents with fever and altered sensorium for two days with rashes on legs as shown. Her BP is 70/50 mm Hg, and neck stiffness is present. Lumbar puncture reveals cloudy CSF with 4200 cells/µL, protein level 198 mg/dL, and glucose 21 mg/dL. Which of the following correctly describes the organism causing this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Gram-negative diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose

options.label: C
options.text: Gram-positive cocci, catalase negative, bacitracin sensitive

options.label: D
options.text: Gram-positive diplococci (lanceolate), catalase negative, optochin sensitive

questions.correct_answer: B. Gram-negative diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gram-negative diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neisseria meningitidis is a Gram-negative diplococcus that ferments glucose and maltose, commonly causing meningitis with symptoms like fever, rash, neck stiffness, and signs of septic shock (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome).

questions.text: VDRL is an example of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Slide flocculation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The VDRL test is an example of a slide flocculation test, used to detect syphilis by observing clumping reactions between cardiolipin antigens and antibodies on a glass slide. It differs from agglutination tests, which involve larger particles like cells or bacteria.
  • ➤ slide flocculation

questions.text: Oil paint appearance on nutrient agar is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "oil paint appearance" on nutrient agar is a distinctive feature of Staphylococcus aureus due to its golden-yellow pigment production, making it different from other bacteria like Streptococcus pyogenes, Bordetella pertussis, and Haemophilus influenzae.
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis?

options.label: B
options.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

options.label: C
options.text: Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.correct_answer: B. Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichomonas vaginalis exhibits twitching or jerky motility on wet saline mount due to its five flagella and is an STD that exists only in trophozoite form, without any cystic stage.
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:

questions.text: Medusa head colonies on nutrient agar are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anthrax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Medusa head appearance is a classic characteristic of Bacillus anthracis colonies on nutrient agar due to the interlocking and filamentous nature of its growth, making it distinct from other bacterial species like Pneumococcus, Legionella, and Brucella.

questions.text: What is correct about the schematic image of Salmonella typhi?

options.label: A
options.text: A = H antigen, B = Vi antigen, C = O antigen

options.label: B
options.text: A = Vi antigen, B = H antigen, C = O antigen

options.label: C
options.text: A = H antigen, B = O antigen, C = Vi antigen

options.label: D
options.text: A = O antigen, B = Vi antigen, C = H antigen

questions.correct_answer: A. A = H antigen, B = Vi antigen, C = O antigen
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A = H antigen, B = Vi antigen, C = O antigen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Salmonella typhi contains three antigens: H (flagella-associated), Vi (slime layer), and O (cell wall-associated). The H antigen is highly antigenic, while the Vi antigen is the least antigenic.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clonorchis sinensis infection increases the risk of cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer).
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Oncogenic organisms
  • ➤ Oncogenic organisms

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory tests is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea?

options.label: A
options.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.correct_answer: A. Antigen detection in the stool sample
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Antigen detection in the stool sample

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary diagnostic method for rotavirus infection is antigen detection in the stool, which is especially important for diagnosing diarrhea in infants and young children.

questions.text: A boy presented with a fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plasmodium falciparum is the only species that produces the HRP-2 antigen, making it detectable through specific rapid tests.

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache, and neck rigidity. CSF analysis showed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism?

options.label: B
options.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar

options.label: C
options.text: Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies

options.label: D
options.text: It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.correct_answer: C. Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Haemophilus influenzae is a pleomorphic gram-negative bacillus that can cause meningitis in children and is identified by its satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar.

questions.text: Identify the species of microfilaria:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Brugia malayi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To differentiate microfilariae, it is important to note whether they are sheathed and the pattern of nuclei in the tail. Brugia malayi has a sheath with two terminal nuclei in the tail, Wuchereria bancrofti is sheathed with no nuclei in the tail tip, and Loa loa is sheathed with nuclei extending to the tail tip.

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ceftriaxone is the first-line treatment for gonorrhea, and it should be given to both the patient and their sexual partner(s) to prevent reinfection and control the spread of the disease.

questions.text: The following pathogen does not satisfy “Koch's postulates” –
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lepra bacilli (Mycobacterium leprae)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mycobacterium leprae (Lepra bacilli) does not satisfy Koch's postulates due to its inability to grow in artificial culture. Remember the mnemonic LPG for the organisms that do not satisfy Koch's criteria: Mycobacterium leprae, Treponema pallidum, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • ➤ LPG

questions.text: In the transmission of malaria, mosquito bite transfers:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sporozoite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sporozoite is the infective form of the malaria parasite that is transmitted from the Anopheles mosquito to humans through a bite. Once in the human bloodstream, the sporozoites travel to the liver to initiate the next phase of the malaria lifecycle.
  • ➤ sporozoite

questions.text: Terminal spined eggs are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Schistosoma haematobium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schistosoma haematobium produces eggs with a terminal spine , which is a key feature for identifying this species. In contrast, S. mansoni has a lateral spine, and S. japonicum has a small knob. Remembering these differences is crucial for correctly diagnosing and differentiating between the various species of Schistosoma.
  • ➤ terminal spine

questions.text: A patient addressing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm³, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm³, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dengue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dengue fever is characterized by fever, severe muscle and joint pain, thrombocytopenia, and a tendency to bleed. It is important to recognize the different stages of dengue, particularly the dangerous transition to dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) and dengue shock syndrome (DSS).

questions.text: The only ovo-viviparous parasite is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Strongyloides

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The only ovo-viviparous nematode is Strongyloides stercoralis, meaning it lays eggs that hatch into larvae almost immediately. This is a distinguishing characteristic that sets it apart from other nematodes like Ascaris, Enterobius, and Ancylostoma, which are all oviparous .
  • ➤ ovo-viviparous
  • ➤ oviparous

questions.text: Lipid envelope is found in which virus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Herpes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A lipid envelope is found in certain viruses, like Herpesviruses, which helps them in immune evasion but makes them more sensitive to environmental factors. In contrast, Reo and Picorna viruses are non-enveloped and more stable in the environment due to their naked capsid
  • ➤ lipid envelope
  • ➤ non-enveloped

questions.text: A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rickettsia prowazekii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rickettsia prowazekii, the causative agent of epidemic typhus, is transmitted by body lice and presents with a rash that spares the palms and soles, making it distinct among the rickettsial infections.
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:

questions.text: A known case of HIV/AIDS presents with neck pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. He succumbed to the illness. Autopsy is done. Pictures of a section of the brain and histopathological examination (HPE) are given. Most likely causative agent:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cryptococcus neoformans

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cryptococcus neoformans is a capsulated fungus known for causing cryptococcal meningitis in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS. The presence of a thick capsule is a hallmark of this organism, distinguishing it from other potential causes like Toxoplasma gondii, Echinococcus multilocularis, and Herpes simplex virus.
  • ➤ capsulated fungus
  • ➤ cryptococcal meningitis

questions.text: Microfilariae with sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is suggestive of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Brugia malayi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Microfilariae of Brugia malayi are identified by their sheathed appearance and two distinct nuclei at the tail tip, which helps differentiate them from other filarial species like Wuchereria bancrofti and Loa loa.

questions.text: Von Magnus phenomenon is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Von Magnus phenomenon is characterized by an abnormal replicative cycle , resulting in viruses with low infectivity but high levels of hemagglutinin . It occurs when multiple viruses infect a single host cell, leading to defective assembly and production of incomplete virions.
  • ➤ Von Magnus phenomenon
  • ➤ abnormal replicative cycle
  • ➤ viruses with low infectivity
  • ➤ high levels of hemagglutinin

questions.text: Viral plaque is made in the lab for:

options.label: A
options.text: Quantitative assay of infectivity of virus

options.label: C
options.text: Qualitative assay of infectivity of virus

questions.correct_answer: A. Quantitative assay of infectivity of virus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Quantitative assay of infectivity of virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A viral plaque assay is primarily used for the quantitative measurement of the number of infectious viral particles in a sample. Each plaque corresponds to one infectious virus, making it a crucial tool for virologists in assessing the infectivity and concentration of viruses.
  • ➤ viral plaque assay
  • ➤ quantitative measurement

questions.text: Lipschutz bodies are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Herpes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lipschutz bodies are characteristic intranuclear inclusion bodies seen in cells infected with Herpes simplex virus (HSV) . They are part of Cowdry type A inclusion bodies, and their presence indicates herpesvirus replication within host cells. This helps in distinguishing herpes from other infections such as viral hepatitis, influenza, or conditions like Hodgkin's disease.
  • ➤ Lipschutz bodies
  • ➤ Herpes simplex virus (HSV)
  • ➤ Cowdry type A

questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichophyton rubrum is identified by its red pigment production and pencil-shaped macroconidia, making it a common cause of dermatophytosis, including infections in moist areas like the axilla.

questions.text: All are true about the bacteria shown in the image except:

options.label: C
options.text: Inverted fir tree appearance in gelatin stab

questions.correct_answer: B. McFadyean's reaction with giemsa stain
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) McFadyean's reaction with Giemsa stain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bacillus anthracis is characterized by its bamboo stick appearance, inverted fir tree pattern in gelatin stab, and can be isolated using PLET medium. McFadyean's reaction involves methylene blue stain , not Giemsa stain , to highlight the capsule of Bacillus anthracis.
  • ➤ McFadyean's reaction
  • ➤ methylene blue stain
  • ➤ Giemsa stain

questions.text: Which of the statement is not true for endotoxins:

options.label: A
options.text: These are lipopolysacaride components of outer membrane of gram negative bacteria

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) They are highly antigenic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endotoxins are components of the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria, are lipopolysaccharides, heat stable, and cannot be converted into toxoids. Unlike exotoxins, they are less antigenic.

questions.text: Which is correct of the parasite shown below?

options.label: A
options.text: A = Tenia solium, B = Tenia saginata

options.label: B
options.text: A = Tenia saginata, B = Tenia solium

options.label: C
options.text: A = Hymenolepis nana, B = Dipyllidium caninum

options.label: D
options.text: A = Dipyllidium caninum, B = Hymenolepis nana

questions.correct_answer: A. A = Tenia solium, B = Tenia saginata
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A = Tenia solium, B = Tenia saginata

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tenia solium is identified by the presence of four suckers along with a rostellum and hooklets, while Tenia saginata has four suckers without a rostellum or hooklets. Tenia solium is "armed," while Tenia saginata is "unarmed."

questions.text: The discovery of "gene transformation" came from the study of one of the following bacteria:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Streptococcus pneumoniae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Griffith experiment demonstrated the concept of gene transformation using Streptococcus pneumoniae. It showed that genetic material could be transferred between bacterial cells, leading to a change in their characteristics.

questions.text: True about Streptococcus pyogenes are all except:

options.label: D
options.text: Glomerulonephritis is due to antigenic cross-reactivity

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Causes only localized infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcus pyogenes can cause both localized and systemic infections, including immune-mediated complications like rheumatic fever and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. It is incorrect to state that it "causes only localized infection" since its impact can be widespread.

questions.text: One of the following about Corynebacterium diphtheriae is wrong:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gram negative

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Corynebacterium diphtheriae is a Gram-positive rod that forms a characteristic "Chinese letter" pattern and contains metachromatic granules. It is prevented through immunization with the DPT vaccine.

questions.text: The capsule of Bacillus anthracis is formed of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Polypeptide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The capsule of Bacillus anthracis is uniquely composed of a polypeptide, specifically poly-D-glutamate, distinguishing it from other bacterial capsules that are typically made of polysaccharides.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered to be the best for the detection of Clostridium difficile?
questions.correct_answer: B. Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For accurate diagnosis of Clostridium difficile infection, use a combination of the GDH enzyme assay and toxin detection, ensuring both the presence of the bacterium and its toxigenic potential are confirmed.

questions.text: Arrangement of lens from eye to source of light in a light microscope:

options.label: A
options.text: Ocular lens : Subjective lens : Condensor lens

questions.correct_answer: A. Ocular lens : Subjective lens : Condensor lens
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ocular lens : Subjective lens : Condenser lens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a light microscope, the arrangement of lenses from the observer’s eye to the light source is: ocular lens, objective (subjective) lens, and then condenser lens.

questions.text: A 24-year-old young male presents with persistent diarrhea and loss of weight. Examination reveals signs of moderate dehydration such as dry tongue and loss of skin turgor. Endoscopy is performed, and biopsy is sent for HPE. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Giardiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giardia lamblia is a common cause of chronic diarrhea and malabsorption, particularly associated with exposure to contaminated water. It has a distinctive "teardrop" shape with four pairs of flagella, visible in duodenal biopsies.

questions.text: Which of the following amoebae does not have a neuropathogenic effect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dientamoeba

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Among the listed amoebae, Dientamoeba does not affect the nervous system, whereas Naegleria fowleri, Acanthamoeba, and Balamuthia are known to cause severe brain infections and are classified as neuropathogenic.

questions.text: Scalded skin syndrome is caused by the following toxin of Staphylococcus aureus:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Exfoliative toxin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSS) is caused by the exfoliative toxin of Staphylococcus aureus, which results in the separation of the skin layers, leading to characteristic skin peeling.

questions.text: Which causative organism is responsible for this disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Coxsackie virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) is caused by Coxsackievirus A, and is characterized by vesicular lesions in the mouth, hands, and feet.

questions.text: A diabetic truck driver presents to you with cough and breathlessness. A diagnosis of pneumonia was confirmed, and histopathological examination revealed dichotomous branching, as shown below. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Aspergillus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergillus is identified by its septate hyphae with 45-degree branching, making it a common cause of opportunistic fungal infections in immunocompromised patients, including those with diabetes or HIV.

questions.text: In nutrient agar, the concentration of agar is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The standard concentration of agar in nutrient agar, a solid culture medium, is 2%, providing the ideal consistency for bacterial growth.

questions.text: All the following are examples of enriched media except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bile salt agar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enriched media are designed to support the growth of fastidious organisms by adding extra nutrients such as blood or serum. Bile salt agar is not enriched but rather selective, used for isolating specific types of bacteria.

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sandfly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is transmitted by the bite of the sandfly, and it is characterized by fever, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, and the presence of Leishmania amastigotes (LD bodies) in macrophages.

questions.text: Thin blood smear for malaria is used to identify:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Type of parasite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thin blood smear in malaria diagnosis is used for identifying the specific type of Plasmodium parasite, allowing for species differentiation, which is crucial for appropriate treatment.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1-A; 2-C; 3-D; 4-B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Henderson-Paterson bodies are indicative of Molluscum contagiosum. Decoy cells are seen in BK polyoma virus infection. Koilocytes are a hallmark of HPV infection. "Owl's eye" inclusion bodies are characteristic of CMV infection.
  • ➤ Henderson-Paterson bodies are indicative of Molluscum contagiosum.
  • ➤ Decoy cells are seen in BK polyoma virus infection.
  • ➤ Koilocytes are a hallmark of HPV infection.
  • ➤ "Owl's eye" inclusion bodies are characteristic of CMV infection.

questions.text: A 22-year old girl is brought to the casualty with a history of fever, confusion, and neck stiffness for 2 days. A purpuric rash is present on her extremities (see picture). BP is 70/50 mmHg. Lumbar puncture sample shows a cloudy CSF with TLC 4200 cells/mm³, 91% neutrophils, protein: 198 mg/dl, glucose: 21 mg/dl. The causative organism is a:

options.label: B
options.text: Gram-positive cocci in chains, catalase-negative, bacitracin-sensitive

options.label: C
options.text: Gram-negative diplococcus, ferments glucose and maltose

questions.correct_answer: C. Gram-negative diplococcus, ferments glucose and maltose
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gram-negative diplococcus, ferments glucose and maltose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neisseria meningitidis is a Gram-negative diplococcus that causes meningitis, particularly in young adults, often presenting with fever, neck stiffness, purpuric rash, and shock. It can be differentiated from other Neisseria species by its ability to ferment both glucose and maltose.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe, and the test shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe that is oxidase positive and known for causing severe infections in burn patients. It produces Exotoxin A , which disrupts host cell function by inhibiting protein synthesis. The identification of this organism through biochemical testing, including the oxidase test, is crucial for proper diagnosis and treatment.
  • ➤ Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe that is oxidase positive and known for causing severe infections in burn patients.
  • ➤ strict aerobe
  • ➤ oxidase positive
  • ➤ It produces Exotoxin A , which disrupts host cell function by inhibiting protein synthesis.
  • ➤ Exotoxin A
  • ➤ The identification of this organism through biochemical testing, including the oxidase test, is crucial for proper diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A young HIV patient with recurrent lesions over genitals as shown in the image. What is the expected microscopic finding in this lesion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intracytoplasmic inclusion body

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Molluscum contagiosum presents with characteristic umbilicated lesions and is identified microscopically by the presence of intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies called Henderson-Peterson bodies.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enveloped ss RNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles is caused by an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus and is characterized by symptoms such as Koplik spots and a maculopapular rash.
  • ➤ enveloped single-stranded RNA virus

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin is associated with food poisoning, especially in foods like cream-filled pastries, causing symptoms such as nausea and vomiting within 2 to 6 hours of ingestion due to its short incubation period.
  • ➤ Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. What is the enrichment medium used to isolate the organism from the stool sample?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Selenite F broth

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Selenite F broth is the enrichment medium of choice for isolating Shigella from stool samples, particularly in cases of dysentery where blood is present in the stool.
  • ➤ Selenite F broth
  • ➤ Shigella

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Motility of the most likely causative organism can be detected by which of the following microscopes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dark field microscope

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dark field microscopy is the preferred method for visualizing the motility of Treponema pallidum , the causative organism of syphilis, directly from a sample taken from a painless genital ulcer.
  • ➤ Dark field microscopy
  • ➤ Treponema pallidum

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the vector shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Orientia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orientia tsutsugamushi , the cause of scrub typhus, is transmitted by chigger mites and not by hard ticks, differentiating it from other diseases like Babesia and Ehrlichia that are tick-borne.
  • ➤ Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • ➤ chigger mites

questions.text: A patient came in OPD with complaints of pain in the genital area. On examination, there was a painful vesicle, associated with painful LAP (lymphadenopathy). What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) HSV2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HSV2 causes painful genital vesicles with painful lymphadenopathy and is a common cause of genital herpes. Understanding the nature of the lesions and their pain characteristics is crucial for differential diagnosis in sexually transmitted infections.
  • ➤ HSV2
  • ➤ painful genital vesicles
  • ➤ painful lymphadenopathy

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He had a history of contact with multiple sexual partners. He was diagnosed as HIV positive 6 months back and is poorly adherent to his medications. The fungal culture of sputum was negative. On Gomori methamine silver staining, the cells showed darkly stained crescent-shaped cysts. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pneumocystis jerovecii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumocystis jerovecii infection is common in HIV patients with low CD4 counts and presents with characteristic crescent-shaped cysts on Gomori methenamine silver staining.

questions.text: A lady from West Bengal presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Leishmania tropica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leishmania tropica is the causative agent of cutaneous leishmaniasis, characterized by skin ulcers and erythema. It is endemic in regions like West Bengal, India, and is identified through the presence of kinetoplasts in biopsy samples. The vector for this disease is the sandfly, which transmits the infective promastigote form.

questions.text: The disease that spreads rapidly, involving many persons in a particular area at the same time is known as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Epidemic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A disease that spreads rapidly and involves many people in a specific area is classified as an epidemic . If it spreads globally, it becomes a pandemic.
  • ➤ epidemic

questions.text: Transfer of DNA by bacteriophage is known as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Transduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transduction is the mechanism of genetic transfer in which a bacteriophage mediates the transfer of DNA from one bacterium to another. This process is distinct from other forms of genetic recombination such as transformation and conjugation .
  • ➤ Transduction
  • ➤ transformation
  • ➤ conjugation
